author: Sharmila Vaidyanathan
title: Climate change is disrupting the human gut in a new path to illness - The Hindu
text:
Climate-driven food shortage and undernourishment could affect the composition of the human gut microbiota, exacerbating the effects of climate change on human health, according to a new review article published in The Lancet Planetary Health .
The article comes on the heels of a growing number of studies that highlight the key role food and nutrition play in maintaining a healthy microbial population in the human gut, leading to better metabolic and intestinal health.
Diversity disrupted According to the review, climate-induced changes in the yield and nutritional quality of plants, seafood, meat, and dairy could disrupt this microbial diversity, tipping the balance towards microbial strains associated with malnutrition and particular diseases.
The review also warns that these effects will be more pronounced in low and middle-income countries (LMICs) since these regions face the brunt of climate stressors, including higher temperature and atmospheric carbon dioxide, which affect their agricultural output and increase render deficiencies in these areas more common.
Indigenous communities that depend more than other demographic groups on local food sources and which have been shown to have greater gut microbial diversity may also be more susceptible to climate-related changes, the review reads.
Research has already found that high atmospheric carbon dioxide levels can diminish the quantity of plant micronutrients like phosphorus, potassium, zinc, and iron, along with protein concentrations in vital crops such as wheat, maize and rice. These effects add to the complexities that affect the gut microbiota.
While the effects of food and nutrition are direct, the review also examined the role of changes in water, soil, and other environmental microbiota as a result of climate change.
A fine balance In another recent review, published in Dialogues in Health , researchers from the Indian Institute of Public Health, Gandhinagar, analysed the impact of heat on human and animal health in India. They found that reports of foodborne and waterborne infectious diseases and malnutrition increase with heat.
Although these findings mirror common knowledge about food and water-related illnesses in warmer weather, the resulting implications for gut dysbiosis — the imbalance in gut microbial populations — also need to be considered for future heat-related mitigation efforts, The Lancet review said.
“While we know and research various effects of climate change on human health, one aspect remains understudied — the effects of changing climate on the microbial communities in the human gut,” Elena Litchman, author of the review in The Lancet and the MSU Foundation professor of aquatic ecology at Michigan State University, said. “This, in part, could be explained by the fact that researchers studying human microbiota do not necessarily think about it in a climate change context.”
The human gut is home to about 100 trillion bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and viruses. Bacteria are this group’s predominant members. The microbes’ overall diversity in the gut influences several aspects of human well-being, including immunity, maintaining glucose levels, and metabolism.
According to a 2018 analysis in The BMJ , lower bacterial diversity has been observed in atopic eczema, types I and II diabetes, and inflammatory bowel disease, among other conditions. Researchers are also exploring how gut dysbiosis changes the central nervous system and leads to neurological disorders.
More research attention The gut microbiome — the collective genome of the microbes in the gut — has far more genes than the human genome, producing thousands of metabolites that affect the individual’s health and development.
“Our understanding of the gut microbiota’s role in human health is still evolving,” While climate change is a growing concern in this context, establishing cause and effect is difficult as there are many confounding factors,” Sachit Anand, a paediatric urologist and assistant professor at AIIMS, New Delhi, said. In his research, Anand examines the role of gut microbiota in congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
He added that understanding the interactions between the microbiota, the host, and the environment is now gaining more research attention, especially when evaluating an individual’s susceptibility to specific diseases. As climate change becomes a key influencing factor in this ‘triad’, its impact cannot be ignored moving forward, he said.
It may be tempting to examine these interdependencies in a linear manner: i.e. that climate-induced changes in crops affect the diet and thus the gut microbiota, or that climate-induced increases in temperatures make enteric infections more prevalent, ultimately disrupting the gut’s microbial population. But both Litchman and Tarini Shankar Ghosh, assistant professor at Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology Delhi, warned that many of these stressors are often playing out simultaneously.
As a computational biologist, Ghosh is interested in patterns in data about the human gut microbiome.
“If you take the example of low-income groups residing in urban environments, you are looking at the impacts of temperature, pollution, lack of quality food, and water supply,” he explained. “There are multiple factors that are disrupting the gut microbiota at the same time.”
A new science Ghosh also said dysbiosis has been found to be a diagnostic signature in many disease states. According to him, this means it is not just the tipping of the balance towards unfavourable microbial populations that is concerning: dysbiosis also signals a loss of interdependence between ‘normal’ microbial strains, leading to a loss of several metabolic functions in the host.
“What we need right now is to generate more data to understand how the so-called good bacteria interact with each other and benefit the host. Data generation must go hand-in-hand with connecting this information to climate change, so we know what is happening,” Ghosh said.
Thus, Litchman said, a multidisciplinary approach with researchers from disparate fields coming together is vital to understand the effects of climate change on human gut microbiota. But along with a lack of awareness of climate change’s effects, a paucity of funding programmes to enable such interdisciplinary and international research is a major impediment to future research of this nature, she added.
On the flip side, with advances in computational biology and metagenomics — analyses of the genetic makeup of microorganisms in a given environment — researchers are inching closer to unearthing some of the gut microbiota’s secrets. For example, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research, Bhopal, professor Vineet Kumar Sharma has developed an open-access database named GutBugBD . It provides information about how the gut microbiome can interact with and alter specific nutraceuticals and drugs, paving the way for therapeutic approaches to modulate gut microbiota in response to various changes.
This is just the start, according to Sharma: “At the moment, we are merely doing broader surveys of the gut microbiota to understand what is there and how they are functioning. Even if we introduce healthy microbiota through, say, probiotics, we cannot know if the response will be the same between two individuals. Each person’s gut microbiota is unique, and understanding this uniqueness is important for the way forward.”
Sharmila Vaidyanathan is an independent writer from Bengaluru.
Published - May 08, 2025 05:30 am IST

author: Jacky
title: Half of police forces not investigating crime properly
text:
Responding to the data, a Home Office source said ministers expected a “zero tolerance” approach to all crimes committed by police, with forces agreeing in September to pursue “all lines of investigation for all crimes.” , without exception”.
The source said: “Since March, there have been record numbers of police and more than £500m extra has been invested. “These additional resources should result in a significant increase in the number of crimes solved.”
The figures emerge from the Telegraph’s analysis of the results of inspections of all 43 forces in 2021/22 against eight criteria.
Forces are rated on metrics including looking after their workforce, offering good value for money and treating the public with respect, but when judged solely on crime investigation, ratings fall.
They scored worse on these metrics than on other criteria such as crime prevention, treating the public with fairness and respect, and value for money.
No force was rated “outstanding” in either investigating crime or responding to the public. Outstanding is the top level of five levels of performance, which then range from good, adequate, requiring improvement, and inadequate.
Three forces were deemed inadequate to investigate crimes and 19 of them were judged to “require improvement”. Eight were assessed as “inadequate” in their response to the public, and another 17 “required improvement.”
The Telegraph’s analysis was based on inspections from 2021/22, covering all 43 forces over the same period to allow a fair comparison. The actions of five forces – the Metropolitan Police, West Midlands, Devon and Cornwall, Staffordshire and Wiltshire – are so worrying that they are currently under special measures.

author: Yahoo奇摩遊戲編輯部
title: 回歸線娛樂2025漫博《藥師少女的獨語》專屬展區與《AS ONE》造景首度曝光
text:
回歸線娛樂2025漫博《藥師少女的獨語》專屬展區與《AS ONE》造景首度曝光 Yahoo奇摩遊戲編輯部 2025年7月23日 週三 下午8:17
動畫代理商「回歸線娛樂 TROPICS ENTERTAINMENT」盛大參展2025漫畫博覽會，開展首日即火力全開、釋出多項令人熱血沸騰的重磅消息！現場驚喜揭曉備受矚目的話題神作——超人氣動畫《藥師少女的獨語》專屬展區！
回歸線娛樂參展2025漫畫博覽會曝光《藥師少女的獨語》展區，帶來重磅消息快閃店首站高雄登場！（來源：回歸線娛樂官方提供） 而備受期待的《藥師少女的獨語》快閃店也同步宣布首站將於8月30日高雄駁二特區自行車倉庫登場，勢必掀起朝聖熱潮！漫博現場展區將隆重展出高人氣角色「貓貓」與「壬氏」等精美立牌，務必把握短短五天拍照時間，絕對不能錯過與人氣角色合照的機會！此外，由靜野孔文與《新世紀福音戰士》角色設計師貞本義行聯手打造的全新動畫電影《AS ONE》獨家造景全球首次曝光！本作由智寶國際參與製作委員會，現場主視覺展現出強烈的神秘與科幻氛圍，讓觀眾能搶先一睹貞本義行筆下全新角色設計的風采。
靜野孔文與貞本義行強力聯手製作動畫電影《AS ONE》獨家造景全球首次曝光（來源：回歸線娛樂官方提供） 回歸線娛樂攤位更匯集超過百款新番周邊商品，包含《藥師少女的獨語》、《WITCH WATCH 魔女守護者》、《在沖繩喜歡上的女孩方言講得太過令人困擾》、《mono女孩》、《轉生成貓咪的大叔》、《快藏好！瑪琪娜同學!!》與《Summer Pockets》等話題作品，眾多首發新品僅在本次漫博限定販售！

author: @scott-uses-git Scott
title: In memory inflate method fails even though writing same data to disk and unzipping is successful
text:
Hey folks,
I have some compressed data in zip format downloaded from a database as blobs (using varchar in SQL). Each blob is a zip archive containing a single file named "data.bin"
I am downloading this data in large batches (~100K), but each blob is relatively small (~100 bytes compressed, ~1000 bytes uncompressed).
I am trying to decompress the data in memory, since writing/unzipping/reading all files to/from disk is quite slow and inefficient.
However, I am not able to find any method in R that can accomplish this, despite the data being easy to unzip once written to disk.
Here is some code showing the problem; the first part runs successfully, whereas the second part does not work for any of the shown methods.
z is a raw vector of bytes containing one entry of compressed data
z
# Write to disk, unzip, read from disk (works) t <- tempfile(fileext = ".zip") writeBin(z, t) zip::unzip(zipfile = t, "data.bin", exdir = dirname(t)) d <- file.path(dirname(t), "data.bin") x <- read_file_raw(d) # Unzip in memory (Does not work) zip::inflate(z) memDecompress(z, "gzip") memDecompress(z, "bzip2") zlib::decompress(z)
I was using Claude AI to try to debug this, I ended up with a function that dumps some useful info about the zip file header.
analyze_zip_structure <- function(bytes) { # Helper function to convert bytes to unsigned integer (little endian) bytes_to_int <- function(bytes) { sum(as.integer(bytes) * 256^(0:(length(bytes)-1))) } # Print first 50 bytes in decimal for analysis cat("First 50 bytes (as integers):
") cat(as.integer(bytes[1:min(50, length(bytes))]), "

") # Verify ZIP signature if (!identical(bytes[1:4], as.raw(c(0x50, 0x4B, 0x03, 0x04)))) { stop("Not a valid ZIP file signature") } # Parse key ZIP header fields cat("ZIP Local File Header Analysis:
") cat("--------------------------------
") cat("Signature (as integers):", as.integer(bytes[1:4]), "
") cat("Version needed:", bytes_to_int(bytes[5:6]), "
") cat("Flags (as integers):", as.integer(bytes[7:8]), "
") cat("Compression method:", bytes_to_int(bytes[9:10]), "
") cat("Last mod time (as integers):", as.integer(bytes[11:12]), "
") cat("Last mod date (as integers):", as.integer(bytes[13:14]), "
") cat("CRC-32 (as integers):", as.integer(bytes[15:18]), "
") cat("Compressed size:", bytes_to_int(bytes[19:22]), "
") cat("Uncompressed size:", bytes_to_int(bytes[23:26]), "
") cat("Filename length:", bytes_to_int(bytes[27:28]), "
") cat("Extra field length:", bytes_to_int(bytes[29:30]), "
") # Get filename filename_length <- bytes_to_int(bytes[27:28]) if (filename_length > 0) { filename <- rawToChar(bytes[31:(30 + filename_length)]) cat("Filename:", filename, "
") } # Calculate where compressed data should start header_end <- 30 + filename_length + bytes_to_int(bytes[29:30]) cat("
Header ends at byte:", header_end, "
") cat("Total file size:", length(bytes), "
") return(header_end + 1) # Return start position of compressed data } analyze_zip_structure(z)
First 50 bytes (as integers): 80 75 3 4 20 0 0 8 8 0 36 183 104 89 131 32 64 7 99 0 0 0 86 4 0 0 8 0 0 0 100 97 116 97 46 98 105 110 237 145 235 10 128 32 12 133 191 65 143 217 ZIP Local File Header Analysis: -------------------------------- Signature (as integers): 80 75 3 4 Version needed: 20 Flags (as integers): 0 8 Compression method: 8 Last mod time (as integers): 36 183 Last mod date (as integers): 104 89 CRC-32 (as integers): 131 32 64 7 Compressed size: 99 Uncompressed size: 1110 Filename length: 8 Extra field length: 0 Filename: data.bin Header ends at byte: 38 Total file size: 213
Here's what I think is going on (I could be wrong).
There is a difference in the zip format depending on whether data is zipped on disk vs in memory Zipping on disk add a header and tail to the data, whereas zipping in memory does not.
The data I am getting from database into memory includes the header and tail (i.e. it was zipped on disk)
So in the code below, I need to figure out how to unzip z2 in memory
z2
x <- charToRaw("this is a test string") # Zip in memory z1 <- zip::deflate(x)$output # Unzip in memory zip::inflate(z1)$output %>% rawToChar() # Write to disk and zip writeBin(x, "test.bin") zip::zip("test.zip", "test.bin") # Read zip binary data into memory - how to unzip z2 in memory??? z2 <- readBin("test.zip", "raw", n = 1e6)
I would greatly appreciate any help figuring this out, I've searched all over the internet and have not found a solution to this.
Thanks, Scott

author: 证星财报简析
title: 匠心家居（301061）2024年年报简析：营收净利润同比双双增长，盈利能力上升_股票频道_证券之星
text:
据证券之星公开数据整理，近期匠心家居（301061）发布2024年年报。截至本报告期末，公司营业总收入25.48亿元，同比上升32.63%，归母净利润6.83亿元，同比上升67.64%。按单季度数据看，第四季度营业总收入6.99亿元，同比上升49.78%，第四季度归母净利润2.52亿元，同比上升197.2%。本报告期匠心家居盈利能力上升，毛利率同比增幅15.9%，净利率同比增幅26.4%。
该数据高于大多数分析师的预期，此前分析师普遍预期2024年净利润为盈利5.44亿元左右。
本次财报公布的各项数据指标表现尚佳。其中，毛利率39.35%，同比增17.09%，净利率26.8%，同比增26.4%，销售费用、管理费用、财务费用总计7884.57万元，三费占营收比3.09%，同比减32.71%，每股净资产21.36元，同比减8.98%，每股经营性现金流2.96元，同比减28.45%，每股收益4.1元，同比增67.35%
财务报表中对有大幅变动的财务项目的原因说明如下： 销售费用变动幅度为37.79%,原因:与销售相关的人工费、展会费、佣金、差旅费、员工股权激励股份支付费用增加。 管理费用变动幅度为50.22%,原因:与管理相关的人工费、折旧费、中介费、员工股权激励股份支付费用增加。 财务费用变动幅度为-209.52%,原因:汇兑收益、利息收入增加。 研发费用变动幅度为6.56%,原因:新品开发投入加大。 经营活动现金流入小计变动幅度为41.16%,原因:本期销售商品、提供劳务收到的现金增加。 经营活动现金流出小计变动幅度为59.78%,原因:本期购买商品、接受劳务支付的现金增加。 投资活动现金流入小计变动幅度为-14.9%,原因:本期理财产品赎回减少。 投资活动现金流出小计变动幅度为-28.95%,原因:本期理财产品投资减少。 筹资活动现金流出小计变动幅度为63.78%,原因:分配股利变化。 现金及现金等价物净增加额变动幅度为598.76%,原因:年末理财产品到期后未来得及续办、汇率变动对现金及现金等价物的影响增加。 货币资金变动幅度为146.71%,原因:销售增长，货款回笼额增加。 应收款项变动幅度为50.94%,原因:销售增长。 存货变动幅度为83.26%,原因:应对订单增加的存货备货。 使用权资产变动幅度为-18.2%,原因:公司执行新租赁准则确认的资产减少。 租赁负债变动幅度为-36.85%,原因:公司执行新租赁准则确认的负债减少。
证券之星价投圈财报分析工具显示： 业务评价： 公司去年的ROIC为18.94%，资本回报率极强。去年的净利率为26.8%，算上全部成本后，公司产品或服务的附加值高。 偿债能力： 公司现金资产非常健康。 融资分红： 公司上市4年以来，累计融资总额14.54亿元，累计分红总额4.35亿元，分红融资比为0.3。
分析师工具显示：证券研究员普遍预期2025年业绩在7.41亿元，每股收益均值在4.43元。
持有匠心家居最多的基金为永赢睿信混合A，目前规模为16.1亿元，最新净值1.2562（4月23日），较上一交易日上涨1.27%，近一年上涨15.26%。该基金现任基金经理为高楠。
以上内容为证券之星据公开信息整理，由智能算法生成（网信算备310104345710301240019号），不构成投资建议。
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->business reporting and performance

author: Malay Mail
title: PM Anwar confident Malaysia will excel as Asean Summit 2025 host | Malay Mail
text: KUALA LUMPUR, July 12 — Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim has expressed confidence that Malaysia is capable of being the best host for the Asean Summit 2025. He said that the strong cooperation of all parties involved would enable the country to be an excellent host for all the delegates. “Various matters have been discussed to ensure thorough preparations can be made at every level involving ministries and government agencies,” he said. Anwar said this in a Facebook post, accompanied by several photos of him chairing the National Steering Committee Meeting for Malaysia’s Asean Chairmanship 2025 at the Parliament building here yesterday. Foreign Minister Datuk Seri Mohamad Hasan, during the Q&A session in the Dewan Rakyat yesterday, informed that Malaysia has outlined three main pillars as preparations for chairing Asean 2025: security and politics, economy, and socio-culture. He said that as of June, Malaysia has arranged 257 high-level meetings involving national leaders, ministers and officials that will be held next year. — Bernama

organizations.name: national steering committee meeting for malaysia

author: Von dpa
title: Tunneleinsturz in Los Angeles: 31 Arbeiter gerettet
text:
Schnelle Rettung
Tunneleinsturz in Los Angeles: 31 Arbeiter gerettet
Los Angeles (dpa)
Die Sorge ist zunächst groß, als erste Meldungen über einen Tunneleinsturz in Kalifornien bekannt wurden. Doch eine Katastrophe ist ausgeblieben.
Aufatmen in Kalifornien: Nach dem Einsturz eines Tunnels im Großraum der US-Metropole Los Angeles hat die Feuerwehr alle Eingeschlossenen bergen können. 31 Menschen, wohl alle Tunnelarbeiter, seien am Mittwochabend (Ortszeit) lebend und ohne sichtbare Verletzungen gerettet worden, teilte die Feuerwehr mit. Der Unglücksort befindet etwa 30 Kilometer südlich des Zentrums von Los Angeles.
Ersten Berichten der Feuerwehr zufolge gelang es einigen Arbeitern nach dem Einsturz, über einen Berg loser Erde zu klettern. Auf der anderen Seite trafen sie demnach auf Kollegen. Anschließend seien die Eingeschlossenen mit einem Tunneltransportmittel zum Ausgang gebracht worden. Sanitäter versorgten daraufhin die Geretteten und untersuchten sie genauer, hieß es.
Ein großer Rettungseinsatz
Mehr als 100 Einsatzkräfte waren nach Angaben der Feuerwehr zum Unglücksort geeilt, darunter spezialisierte Rettungsteams. Der Einsturz passierte demnach mehr als acht Kilometer vom einzigen Tunneleingang entfernt. Es handele sich um einen im Bau befindlichen Tunnel für die kommunale Abwasserentsorgung, hieß es weiter. Die Ermittlungen zur Ursache des Einsturzes dauern an.
Etwa eine Stunde waren die Arbeiter in dem Tunnel eingeschlossen, meldete CBS News. Der Tunnel sei insgesamt mehr als 11 Kilometer lang und etwas mehr als fünf Meter breit, schrieb der US-Sender unter Berufung auf den Betreiber.

author: Dylan Bailey
title: Montrose Environmental's $4 Million Contract Boosts Sustainability in Mining
text:
Montrose Environmental's $4 Million Contract Boosts Sustainability in Mining
Dylan BaileyUpdated: 04-23-2025 06:10 PM
Montrose Environmental Group Secures Major Contract
Project supports rapidly growing global steel demand with scalable, sustainable solutions.
Recently, Montrose Environmental Group (NYSE: MEG) has made headlines by securing a significant AUD $4 million contract aimed at providing comprehensive environmental services for a considerable mining operation in the Bowen Basin, a vital area known for producing metallurgical coal used in steel manufacturing. This development marks a noteworthy expansion of Montrose's footprint in Australia, a country where the company is heavily invested in promoting sustainable and environmentally responsible mining practices.
This project is a testament to Montrose's commitment to enhancing environmental stewardship, as it will play a crucial role in supporting local industries transitioning to sustainability. By conducting advanced environmental baseline and impact assessments, Montrose will help ensure that the mining operation can develop safely and responsibly, thereby minimizing its ecological footprint. Moreover, the project is set for fast-tracked completion within the coming year, which further underscores Montrose's capability as a trusted partner in resource-intensive sectors.
Supporting the Steel Industry's Shift to Sustainability
The demand for steel worldwide is on the rise, driving industries to seek more sustainable practices. Montrose Environmental is stepping in to support this transition. By leveraging its extensive experience and a top-tier team of experts well-versed in navigating complex regulations, Montrose has positioned itself as a go-to partner for projects centered on responsible mining operations.
Vijay Manthripragada, President and CEO of Montrose Environmental Group, emphasized the significance of this project, stating, "This project reflects the strength of Montrose's strategy and mission and underscores sustained demand for our services despite global uncertainties. Critical global industries, like steel, trust Montrose for our deep industry expertise and proven capabilities. This is why we continue to win and deliver complex environmental contracts that enable our clients to sustainably, responsibly and successfully operate their businesses." This commitment not only boosts Montrose's standing in the industry but also reinforces its strategy of blending economic viability with environmental responsibility.
Comprehensive Environmental Services
Montrose's service offerings are quite extensive, providing a broad spectrum of consulting services in environmental management. These services range from risk assessments and permitting strategies to regulatory compliance and sustainability planning. Through innovative solutions, Montrose enables organizations to pursue data-driven decisions that enhance long-term environmental resilience. This comprehensive approach helps clients tackle immediate business needs while planning for future challenges within an ever-evolving regulatory landscape.
Employee Expertise and Global Network
The strength of Montrose lies in its diverse team of experts, who are dedicated to developing tailored solutions for each project's unique challenges. With approximately 3,400 employees across over 100 locations worldwide, Montrose combines local knowledge with global expertise. This dual approach allows the company to respond effectively and efficiently to the varied requirements of its clients in different regions.
About Montrose Environmental Group
Montrose is a leading environmental solutions firm dedicated to supporting both commercial and government organizations in overcoming the pressing challenges of today while preparing for future demands. With its vast experience and commitment to sustainability, Montrose focuses on delivering innovative, practical solutions encompassing air measurement, regulatory compliance, emergency response, and engineering services.
For anyone interested in learning more about Montrose Environmental Group and their commitment to sustainable practices, detailed information can be found on their official website. They also actively share updates and insights through their LinkedIn profile.
Frequently Asked Questions
What is the value of the contract awarded to Montrose Environmental Group?
The contract awarded to Montrose Environmental Group is valued at AUD $4 million.
What type of services will Montrose provide under this contract?
Montrose will provide comprehensive environmental services, including environmental baseline and impact assessments for a mining operation.
How does this project support the steel industry?
This project supports the steel industry by helping it transition to more sustainable practices through responsible mining operations.
Who is the CEO of Montrose Environmental Group?
The CEO of Montrose Environmental Group is Vijay Manthripragada.
What areas does Montrose Environmental serve?
Montrose Environmental serves clients globally, with a strong presence in Australia and North America, focusing on sustainable solutions across various sectors.

title: Rockford woman's death result of homicide-suicide, police said
text: Sheriff: Rockford woman's death result of homicide-suicide The homicide of a Rockford woman is believed to be the result of domestic violence, according to the Winnebago County Sheriff's Office. Authorities said a 25-year-old woman was shot multiple times Wednesday night in the 2900 block of Searles Avenue. The woman was taken to the hospital where she died from her injuries. While on scene, sheriff deputies found the suspect, a 24-year-old man, dead from what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Authorities said there's no threat to the public. "If you're experiencing domestic violence or abuse, it's crucial to understand that there is no acceptable excuse or justification for any behavior that endangers your well-being," Sheriff Gary Caruana said in a news release. If you are currently in or have been in a violent domestic situation, you're urged to call 911. You can also reach out to the following organizations for assistance: Winnebago County Domestic Violence Assistance Center400 W. State St., Rockford815-516-2440Rockford Family Peace Center315 N. Main Street Rockford779-348-7600Remedies215 Easton Parkway Rockford815-962-6102 The national 24-hour domestic violence hotline can be reached at 1-800-799-7233
